content: How can I help you today?

Well, I've just been struggling to sleep lately. Work has been really stressful, and I can’t seem to turn off my thoughts at night. My partner convinced me to give this a try, even though I’m not sure how much this will help.

Thank you for sharing that—it sounds like things have been overwhelming for you lately. Struggling with sleep can make everything feel even more difficult, especially when you're managing stress from work. It's great that you have someone supportive like your partner encouraging you to explore this. Would you like to talk more about what's been weighing on your mind or your recent experiences with sleep?

It’s mostly work that’s been weighing on me. I’m worried about the stock market and how it’s going to affect my company. If there are layoffs, I honestly feel like I’d be one of the first to go, and I don’t know how I’d provide for my family if that happens. That thought keeps running through my head every night when I’m trying to fall asleep.

That sounds like such a heavy worry to carry, especially considering the responsibilities you feel toward providing for your family. It’s understandable that those concerns would make it hard to sleep. Facing uncertainty like that can be really tough, especially when it feels out of your control. How have you been managing these thoughts so far?

I haven’t really been managing them, to be honest. I just lie there at night, and my mind keeps going over all the worst-case scenarios. I’ve tried distracting myself, like watching TV or scrolling on my phone, but it doesn’t seem to help. It’s like I can’t shut my brain off.

It must be exhausting to feel stuck in that cycle every night. It sounds like you’re trying different ways to cope, but the stress is still taking a toll. Sometimes distractions feel like a temporary relief, but those thoughts can keep coming back. What do you think might help you feel a bit more in control of this?

Honestly, I don’t know what would help. I feel like it’s all outside my control, which makes it so overwhelming. Maybe if I knew for certain my job was safe, I’d feel better. But I don’t, so I just keep spiraling.

That uncertainty is understandably really tough, especially when your job and family are so important to you. Feeling like you’re stuck without control can make it hard to find relief or direction. Would it help to explore other ways of finding some peace or clarity in the middle of this? Or if you prefer, we could talk more about how these feelings have been affecting your day-to-day life.
I'm here to listen whenever you're ready. Take your time—what feels most important for you to talk about right now?
I'm here to listen whenever you're ready. Take your time—what feels most important for you to talk about right now?

It’s okay to take a moment—this is your space, and you can share whatever feels right. When you’re ready, we can continue talking about your sleep, your worries about work, or anything else that’s on your mind.

It’s just really hard to figure out where to start. Everything feels interconnected—if I could just sleep, maybe I’d feel more in control, or if I felt more secure at work, maybe I’d be able to sleep better. It’s just a lot all at once.

That sense of everything being tangled together can feel so overwhelming. It makes sense that you're not sure where to begin, especially when it feels like one thing impacts another. You're recognizing that both sleep and work security are important, and it’s okay to take one small step at a time. What do you feel would be a helpful area to explore first?

It sounds like you’re caught in a frustrating cycle, and I get that it’s hard to even know where to begin. Maybe we can try breaking it down together—what feels like the most pressing thing on your mind when you lay awake at night?

Your concerns about work seem like the loudest thoughts keeping you awake, and that makes sense given how deeply they affect your sense of security and responsibilities toward your family. If you'd like, we could explore small ways to ease those nighttime thoughts, or perhaps find ways to focus on what gives you strength, even during uncertain times. Where would you like to start?

The most pressing thing is definitely worrying about losing my job. It feels like I have so much riding on it—providing for my family, being a good partner, making sure the bills are paid. I can't stop playing out worst-case scenarios in my head when I'm lying in bed.

You’re carrying a lot on your shoulders, and your concern for your family and responsibilities shows how much you care about them. It's understandable that these worst-case scenarios would feel urgent and overwhelming, especially at night when it’s quieter and your mind has space to wander. What helps you feel any sense of steadiness or strength in moments like these, even if it's just a little?

You’re carrying such a heavy mental load—it’s no wonder it’s hard to shut your mind off at night. Trying to anticipate and plan for the worst is exhausting, especially when it feels like so much is out of your control. Have you ever tried anything to refocus your mind or challenge those worst-case thoughts when they come up?

It sounds like your thoughts about work and providing for your family are deeply tied to what matters most to you. Sometimes, those values can feel like a source of pressure, but they can also be a source of strength. When those worst-case thoughts show up, do you find it helpful to focus on what’s within your control, or what gives you hope? Or has anything else worked in moments like these?
